text: The Akt Signaling Pathway Contributes to the Regulation of Necroptosis
We next determined whether the necroptosis - associated increase in Thr308 phosphorylation results in an increase in Akt kinase activity .

Under necroptotic conditions , we observed an increase in the phosphorylation of multiple known Akt substrates ( Forkhead box class O ( FoxO ) proteins , GSK-3 kinases and mouse <extra_id_0> double minute 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> MDM2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) ) as well as downstream molecules ( <extra_id_0> p70 ribosomal protein S6 Kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) ( Fig . 5A ) .

In some cases ( <extra_id_0> FoxO1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> FoxO4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> MDM2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a robust increase was observed .

In other cases ( <extra_id_0> FoxO3a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> GSK-3alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and its substrate <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , the changes were less pronounced ( Fig . 5A ) .
The timing of the phosphorylation changes paralleled the increase in Akt phosphorylation ( Fig . 5B , S5A , B ) .

In the case of <extra_id_0> pFoxO1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> we occasionally observed a shift in migration rather than an increase in band intensity ( e.g . comparing Fig . 5A and B ) , suggesting that phosphorylation events in addition to Thr24 take place during necroptosis .
Notably , in all cases the necroptosis - associated increases in Akt substrates were abrogated by Nec-1 ( Fig . 5A , Fig .
S5A , B ) .

Overall , these data suggested that a significant part of the " canonical " Akt signaling network is activated at the onset of necroptotic cell death in a <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> dependent fashion .
Akt kinase is considered to be a pro-survival protein that inhibits apoptosis through the control of multiple effectors including mTORC1 , GSK-3 and others [ 28 ] .
An important question is whether these same molecules reverse their pro-survival roles during necroptosis .
We found that inhibition of mTORC1 by rapamycin , an inhibitor of the mTOR co-factor <extra_id_0> Raptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 29 ] , protected cells from necroptosis ( Fig . 5C ) .
Similarly , the direct mTOR kinase inhibitor Torin1 [ 30 ] and the dual PI3K / mTOR inhibitor PI-103 [ 31 ] also efficiently inhibited necroptosis ( Fig . 5C ) .

Knockdown of mTOR using siRNA further validated the small-molecule inhibitor data indicating a role for mTOR in necroptosis by protecting cells from both zVAD.fmk and <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induced death ( Fig . 5D ) .

mTORC1 regulates translation through activation of <extra_id_0> p70S6 kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and , subsequently , ribosomal protein <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 32 ] .
Notably , a genome-wide siRNA screen [ 10 ] suggested an important role for protein translation in necroptosis .

Consistently , we found that the small molecule inhibitor of <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> PF-4708671 [ 33 ] attenuated necroptosis at the concentrations required to block <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation ( Fig .
S5C , D ) .
Partial siRNA knockdown of <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein attenuated necroptosis as well ( Fig .
S5E ) , suggesting that translational control by <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may play a role in necroptosis .

Overall , while the full repertoire of Akt targets during necroptosis remains to be fully explored , our data provide evidence that the activity of an anti-apoptotic branch of Akt signaling can promote necroptosis .
<extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase , Akt , mTORC1 and JNK control the upregulation of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> accompanying necroptosis .

Hitomi et al . [ 10 ] have recently reported that the induction of necroptosis by zVAD.fmk in L929 cells is associated with increased synthesis of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which potentiates cell death .
Therefore , we examined whether Akt and its effectors contribute to <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis .
Consistent with a <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent increase in <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein ( Fig .

S6A , B ) , we found that <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels increased during necroptosis in L929 cells in a <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Fig .
S6C .

Under serum free conditions , <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone triggered some induction of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , while its combination with zVAD.fmk ( but not zVAD.fmk alone ) caused a pronounced further increase ( Fig . 6A ) .

Conversely , PDGF caused a modest upregulation of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , which was not further increased in the presence of zVAD.fmk ( Fig . 6A ) , demonstrating that activation of necroptosis is specifically accompanied by a marked increase in autocrine <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis .

Further analysis suggested that both Akt and mTORC1 contribute to the upregulation of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA during necroptosis as both small-molecule inhibition and siRNA knockdown of Akt and mTOR reduced <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels in necroptotic cells ( Fig . 6B , C , D ) .

Notably , <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and Akt inhibitors had no effect on the levels of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA in control cells or in the cells stimulated with <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone ( Fig . 6A , B , Fig .
S6C ) , suggesting that these kinases specifically mediate necroptosis - dependent increase in <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis .
